109161.comment:
This is a waste of money and an abuse of power. The bike lanes already exist, why would you try to remove them?
Removing bike lanes will only result in more cars on the road causing greater congestion and worsening traffic. In addition this will cost lives as bike riders will no longer have protection while riding on busy streets.

109164.comment: This government makes many mistakes but this is one of the dumbest yet.  Removing bike lanes will have no impact on traffic flow. In other jurisdictions this has been documented many times.  GTA traffic problems are caused by inadequate transit choices and construction. Removing lanes will discourage cycling, encourage the use of polluting vehicles and result in more injuries to and deaths of cyclists.

109165.comment:
Removing bike lanes will be counterproductive for the stated goal of reducing gridlock.
Those commuting by bike will still need to travel. They will do so either by bike in the main lane (both disruptive and dangerous) or pack the streets in cars.
The only way to reduce congestion is to provide a non-car alternative. This is a plainly political waste of time and money.

109166.comment: Bike lanes should be a city responsibility. Cities have their own experts and long term studies focused on this specific problem. The province should not involve itself in decisions of the city. It is over reach. Furthermore, requiring the removal of bike lanes by cities is costly and un necessary. If the province wants to control the design of city streets, it should pay for 100% of the construction and maintenance of those streets.

109167.comment: This is a totally unnecessary proposal trying to justify itself with reasoning that is unsupported by data - bike lanes dont cause traffic, cars cause traffic. Construction to remove bike lanes will not only worsen the congestion it claims to address, but will also be a gross waste of resources that could be otherwise used to address actual important problems in municipalities. Even if congestion for cars is marginally improved, there is no disputing that more lives will be put at risk if cyclists are not given access to safe roadways and bike lanes, and road deaths are certain to increase if bike lanes are removed. It is inconceivable that the Ontario government has decided that a few minutes of shorter commuting is worth the loss of human life - shameful and stupid.

109168.comment: Your decision to remove bike lanes arbitrarily is short sighted and pro car.  Instead of working with municipalities to come to a solution for congestionsDoug the thug is being heavy handed.  Why don’t you concentrate on improving public transportation. This will not relieve any congestion as bike riders will continue to use the roads and really slow down traffic.

109169.comment: I believe this bill is a massive overreach of provincial jurisdiction and is fundamentally flawed in it's application, lacking any data-driven policy. All available evidence points to bike lanes reducing gridlock and most importantly, saving lives. This bill will directly threaten the people of Ontario and is unconscionable, and waste taxpayer dollars in needless acts of petty municipal vandalism.

109170.comment:
The removal of the Bloor, Yonge and university bike lanes will result in deaths of pedestrians and cyclists, and do nothing to ease gridlock. This is a policy that runs contrary to evidence based planning, and is an affront to the democratic system by overruling the elected will of Toronto council, which has a mandate from Torontonians to build and maintain these bike lanes.
I hope the government is prepared for mass demonstrations and civil disobedience if it moves forward with this plan. The communities who benefit from these bike lanes, and the people who rely on them to travel through the core of the city will not take kindly to this egregious governmental overreach.
Shameful leadership by this government.

109171.comment:

Help fund municipality transportation requests/improvements more. That way they can achieve their goals and make things better for Ontarians as needed for their areas specificities.

109172.comment: Bike lanes are an integral part of the City of Toronto. They allow residents to get wherever they may be going quick and efficiently (not to mention environmentally). The added bike lanes have made it much safer for people to ride their bikes, DECREASING the amount of cars on the road. By removing bike lanes, you are decreasing alternative transport modes and forcing people to take their car and increasing traffic…and that’s just common sense. This bill should be shot down immediately and the Premier should be leaving any municipal roads to the municipal government. If the residents of the  City of Toronto want bike lanes, thats what they deserve. People living in urban areas don’t want to drive 5 min, they want to walk or ride their bike.

109174.comment:
Nike lanes are important infrastructure that fight climate change, reduce traffic, increase user health, and contribute to the bustling, tourist-friendliness of our cities.
Removing them is not only anti-democratic (as bike lanes were a LARGE part of the discourse around the last Toronto municipal election) and anti-science, but it's anti-social and anti-people.
The fact that the province is so casually considering removing them against the express wishes, and investments, of municipalities is a disgusting overreach. You should feel ashamed, but it no seems that you're unable to even feel that anymore.

109175.comment:
If passed, not only will this bill make cycling more dangerous in the city of Toronto, but also possibly increase gridlock by tacitly encouraging more people to use their cars to get around.
Cycling corridors make it easy for people to safely and efficiently engage with many neighbourhoods across the city to the benefit of many small businesses that rely on the kind of engagement that happens from foot traffic and cycling traffic.
Environmentally this would be a decision that is completely incongruous with the international climate goal of creating less fossil fuel reliance.
I am not in favour of this bill.

109177.comment: I implore the government to listen to the experts here. There is no basis in their claim that it is singularly the bike lanes on these three roads causing congestion. There is a complete lack of understand of how proper analysis would and should be carried out. But of course this is beside the point because what is clear is that these lanes are saving lives and moving people quickly down the streets. During rush hour on bloor, 35% of trips are by bike. What happens when the lanes are removed? The following three things are possible 1) these people are now in cars 2) these people take up the full car lane in order to safely bike 3) they add to the already overcrowded Bloor subway line.  Bike lanes provide safety and mobility. They are part of the solution. The removal of existing safety infrastructure is a horrendous act of shortsightedness. If this government is truly concerned with congestion, I beg them to stop mismanaging the backlog of transit projects and take a course in transportation/urban economics to understand how induced demand works with respect to road infrastructure. Further, I am embarrassed and insulted by the government's use of a $200 giveaway in the midst of a housing/health/transit crisis.

109178.comment: This makes zero sense.  Bike lanes reduce traffic, by removing potential car drivers from the road. Getting rid of bike lanes, makes it unsafe to bike in the city, and makes it more likely people will drive instead. This is nothing more than an attack on the safety of Torontonians, and the intelligence of the people too. Naming it "reducing gridlock, saving you time act" does not make it magically work.

109180.comment:
This may be the dumbest thing this government has tried to do and the bar for stupid is extremely high.
Bike lanes are critically important transportation infrastructure that provide safe and efficient transportation. Studies show bike lanes reduce carbon emissions, save lives, and enhance local business. Removing them is bad for traffic, bad for the environment and bad for business.
